thread.title: Halloween in Syracuse: 25 parties, dances and family festivals in Central New York
thread.title_full: Halloween in Syracuse: 25 parties, dances and family festivals in Central New York

author: Katrina Tulloch | ktulloch@syracuse.com
title: Halloween in Syracuse: 25 parties, dances and family festivals in Central New York
text:
Comments Dave and Tim Cooper of Phoenix, N.Y. dress as Bobo and Calypso, the evil clowns at the Trail of Terror in Fulton, N.Y. Katrina Tulloch | ktulloch@syracuse.com 
SYRACUSE, N.Y. -- Not a fan of Halloween? Better stay at home then, Brad*, because the rest of us intend to have a ball. Here are 25 Halloween bashes, haunted tours or festivals where families (or adults only) can enjoy the spooky spirit of Central New York. Mark your calendars and pick your costumes because your next two weekends just became way more fun. 
*Brad Majors is a boring, unadventurous character in "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" who is shocked but ultimately seduced by the wild Dr. Frank-N-Furter, a promiscuous, transvestite scientist. This Halloween, don't be a Brad. 
1. Freak Show The Landmark Theatre will host a medley of Syracuse bands at the 2015 Rock and Roll Freak Show, including Pale Green Stars, Hobo Graffiti, Amerikan Primitive, Spring Street Family Band and The Stacey White Suite. Get our freak on with makeup artists, vendors, drink specials, a costume contest, prizes and haunted tours of the theater on Friday, Oct. 23 and Saturday, Oct. 24. Where: Landmark Theatre at 362 S. Salina St. When: Friday, Oct. 23 at 8 p.m. How much: Admission is $10. 
2. 'Friday the 13th' film festival The Palace Theater will host a Halloween film festival will multiple "Friday the 13th" screenings, plus a feature showing of "Hack-O-Lantern." All films will be shown on 35 mm prints. There will be vendors and special guests in the lobby, and alcohol for guests 21 and older. All films are rated R. 5:30 p.m. - Camp Crystal Lake Haunted Walk (theater lobby) 6 p.m. - One Last Shot (Upstate N.Y. Punk Rock Band) 6:30 p.m. - Hack-O-Lantern 8:15 p.m. - Friday the 13th PT 4: The Final Chapter 9:45 p.m. - One Last Shot 10 p.m. - Friday the 13th Pt 5: A New Beginning 11:45 p.m. - Friday the 13th Pt 6: Jason Lives Where: Palace Theater at 2384 James St. When: Friday, Oct. 23. Doors open at 5:30 p.m. How much: $20 at the door and $15 in advance. Bring a can of food for admission to The Haunted Walk. Advance sale tickets avail at Modern Pop Culture in Armory Square) and online . The Seward House Museum on South Street in Auburn was the home of William Henry Seward, one of the most important American politicians of the 19th century. Stephen D. Cannerelli 
3. Haunted History Tours of Auburn Costumed guides take guests around the Seward House grounds and to the gates of Fort Hill Cemetery, sharing macabre tales of Victorian funeral practices, the assassination attempt on Seward, the spectral sightings of Seward family pets and other spooky accounts of folklore and history. Where: Seward House at 33 South St., Auburn. When: Oct. 23-25 and Oct. 27-30. Tours leave at 6 and 7 p.m. How much: $10; ages 12 and younger, $8. Call 315-252-1283, or go to sewardhouse.org . 
4. Wicked Woods Wicked Woods at Green Lakes State Park will have Halloween fun for all ages: Halloween Headquarters with crafts from 4 to 8 p.m., face painting from 4 to 7 p.m., a Trick-or-Treat Trail on the beach from 4 to 6 p.m. (costumes encouraged), a Haunted Trail from 6:30 to 7:30 p.m. (for braver participants) and a bonfire on the beach at 7 p.m. For more information, call 315-637-5188. Where: Green Lakes State Park at 7900 Green Lakes Rd., Fayetteville. When: Saturday, Oct. 24 from 4 to 8 p.m. How much: Free and open to the public. 
5. 'The Rocky Horror Picture Show' Filming of "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" movie began in October 1974, but the movie officially hit U.S. theaters in August 1975, making this fall the 40th anniversary of the film's release. See the cult classic on the big screen at the Palace Theater, where there will be a Halloween costume contest and cash bar. Where: Palace Theater at 2384 James St. When: Saturday, Oct. 24. Doors open at 6 p.m. There will be a "Killer Klowns from Outer Space" screening at 8:30 p.m. and then "Rocky Horror" screens at 11:30 p.m. How much: Tickets are $15 in advance or $20 at the door. "Rocky Horror" enthusiasts packed the Palace Theater for a 2014 showing of the film. Dancers filled the stage for a dance party leading up to the screening. Photo by Scott Schild. 
6. Murder mystery dinner Come to the Aurora Inn, Rowland House for a three-course dinner and participate in a murder mystery. Your character, story line and costume props are provided, while the rest is up to you. Throughout dinner, investigate clues of the murder and solve the mystery with the help of Dale, your innkeeper and host for the evening. The dinner is for guests 21 and older. Where: Rowland House at 453 Main St., Aurora. When: Saturday, Oct. 24 from 6 to 11 p.m. Check-in at 3 p.m. How much: Packages are $475 per couple, with a wine and cheese reception hour, a three-course paired dinner and overnight accommodations. 
7. Halloween party at The ROAD The Road 's Halloween Party will have treats, crafts, games, music, dancing, pumpkin carving and free pumpkins to take home. There's also a cafe inside to have dinner, drinks and snacks. Where: The Road at 4845 West Seneca Turnpike, Syracuse. When: Saturday, Oct. 24 from 2 to 5 p.m. How much: Free to attend. Meals cost about $8. 
8. 95X Zombie Crawl 2015 The annual 95X Zombie Crawl in downtown Syracuse kicks off at J Ryan's Pub at 5 p.m. Makeup artists will be on hand to "zombify" guests. See the full schedule with stops at Clark's Ale House, Clinton St. Pub and King of Clubs. The finale party is at Syracuse Suds Factory starts at 10 p.m. with live music. Where: Armory Square bars. When: Saturday, Oct. 24 at 5 p.m. How much: $5 to die, $10 to get bitten, $20 to rot. Nate Mezatesta of Syracuse peers around a column during the 2013 KROCK Zombie Ball. Photo by Scott Schild. 
9. KROCK Zombie Ball On Saturday, KROCK will host costume contests, psychics, palm readers, live DJs and a zombie movie on the big screen. Come dressed as one of the undead or have a makeup artist transform you into a brain-eating zombie. Where: Landmark Theatre at 362 S. Salina St. When: Saturday, Oct. 24. Doors open at 8 p.m., party at 9 p.m. and movie at 10 p.m. How much: General admission tickets are $10 in advance at the Landmark Theatre Box Office, by phone, or online at ticketmaster.com. 
10. 'Eerie Halloween' community party Costumes are encouraged at the Chittenango Landing Canal Boat Museum 's Halloween party. The party includes age-appropriate games for young children, a haunted house, crafts, face painting and decorate-your-own pumpkins to take home. (Pumpkins were donated by The Chittenango Lions.) Cider and donuts will be sold. Where: Chittenango Landing Canal Boat Museum, 717 Lakeport Rd., Chittenango. When: Sunday, Oct. 25 from 1 to 4 p.m. How much: Free admission. Madelyn Schneider and Abigail Morse, both 5, of Skaneateles, dance at Zoo Boo, held at Rosamond Gifford Zoo, Syracuse, Oct. 17, 2015. Photo by Kate Collins. Kate Collins | kcollins@syracuse.com 
11. Zoo Boo Rosamond Gifford Zoo will celebrate Halloween with the annual Zoo Boo series. Kids and parents can wear Halloween costumes to the zoo, and see the entire animal collection. Activities include trick-or-treat stations, creepy crawly encounters, games, tattoos, a mega raffle, an inflatable activity center and professional face painting. Where: Rosamond Gifford Zoo at 1 Conservation Place. When: Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 24 and 25 from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Zoo Boo is held rain or shine. How much: $8 per child plus the cost of zoo admission. Advance sale tickets are available for zoo members only. Buy tickets on rosamondgiffordzoo.org/zoo-boo . 
12. Halloween at the library Here's a good weekday option for young families. Dress up in your Halloween costume, listen to spooky music and make Halloween crafts at Northern Onondaga Public Library's party. There will be Halloween snacks and games. Where: Northern Onondaga Public Library at 100 Trolley Barn Ln. in North Syracuse. When: Tuesday, Oct. 27 from 6:30 to 7:30 p.m. How much: Free. Registration is required. 
13. Westcott Halloween Extravaganza Creative Concerts presents Dieselboy Direktor, Quazarr, DJ IsIs, Peeps and Captain Munch for the 5th annual Westcott Halloween Extravaganza. You can also dress up and enter a costume contest to win free shows for the rest of the year. Where: Westcott Theater at 524 Westcott St. When: Thursday, Oct. 29. Doors open at 7 p.m. and the show begins at 7:30 p.m. How much: Ticket prices range from $17-25. 
14. Mall-O-Ween at ShoppingTown Kids can trick-or-treat on a weekday at ShoppingTown Mall stores. Go in costume. Where: ShoppingTown Mall at 3649 Erie Blvd. E. When: Thursday, Oct. 29 from 1-7 p.m. How much: $1 per child and all proceeds benefit The Children's Consortium of CNY. Everson Museum of Art at 401 Harrison St., Syracuse. David Lassman | dlassman@syracuse.com 
15. Halloween Beer Garden 2015 Costumes are encouraged, but not required, for the Everson Museum of Art's Halloween Beer Garden evening. Take a tour to hear dark stories about art in the museum's permanent collection or dance to the "Monster Mash" below the installation art of Three Graces. Guests can enjoy local craft brews, have a fortune told by psychic medium or design a pumpkin. Prizes will be awarded for the best costume and top pumpkin design. Join us for this spirited evening of art, local craft brews, and Halloween treats. Where: Everson Museum of Art at 401 Harrison St. When: Thursday, Oct. 29 from 5 to 8 p.m. How much: $10 for Everson Museum members and $15 for non-members. 
16. Singers Freak Show For the ninth year in a row, Singers Karaoke Club will host a pre-Halloween event with live band performances and a magic show, in addition to karaoke. At the Singers "Freak Show," there will be live performances by acoustic duo Junkhead, indie rockers Department and gothic folk musicians Zadoc's Eternal Circus. Enjoy "scary-oke karaoke" between live acts and Halloween drink specials like "Bark At The Moon" bombs, "Snake Charmer's Elixer" and $3 pints of Jack-O Traveler Pumpkin Ale. Where: Singers Karaoke Club at 1345 Milton Ave., Solvay. When: Thursday, Oct. 29 at 8:30 p.m. How much: No cover charge. Bring your wallet for drinks and food. 
17. Oneida cemetery tour Molly Jessup will give a tour of the Oneida Community Cemetery on Halloween. The tour will follow a brief talk in the Big Hall on how the Oneida community understood death and the afterlife and how the cemetery (size/style of most gravestones) reflected the community's beliefs. Guests must be able to walk from the Mansion House to the cemetery located on the Oneida Community Golf Course. Where: Oneida Community Cemetery at 170 Kenwood Ave., Oneida. When: Sat. Oct. 31 from 10 a.m. to noon. How much: Call 315-363-0745 to register. Donations will be accepted. 
18. Trick-or-Treat at Great Northern Mall Little ghosts and goblins are invited to enjoy a warm, safe trick-or-treat event at Great Northern Mall. Participating retailers will have an orange pumpkin in the window and plenty of candy to give away. Don't forget to get a photo in your costume at the mall's festive photo station. Where: Great Northern Mall at 4155 State Route 31, Clay. When: Saturday, Oct. 31 at 3 p.m. How much: Free and open to the public. 
19. Trick-or-Treat at Destiny USA Destiny USA will host a trick-or-treat event on Halloween with a movie, "Alvin and the Chipmunks Meet Frankenstein," playing in the Canyon every hour from 4 to 7 p.m. Adults 21 years or older must accompany trick-or-treaters 17 or younger. Participating businesses will have a Halloween sticker on their window or door. Where: Destiny USA at 9090 Destiny USA Dr. When: Trick or treating will start at 5 p.m. and end at 7 p.m. on Saturday, Oct. 31. How much: Free and open to the public. The World Lounge & Martini Bar reopened in Hanover Square in September 2009. Don Cazentre | dcazentre@syracuse.com 
20. Halloween Bash at World Lounge World Lounge Martini Bar in Hanover Square will host its annual Halloween Bash on Oct. 31 with drink specials and costume contests for the scariest, most original and sexiest costumes of the night. Where: World Lounge Martini Bar at 134 E. Genesee St. When: Sat., Oct. 31 at 10 p.m. How much: No cover charge. World Lounge will also host a Halloween College Night on Oct. 30 at 9 p.m., but with a $5 cover charge. 
21. Singers Halloween Costume Party Singers Karaoke Club will also host a Halloween party with cash prizes for the funniest costume, scariest costume, sexiest costume, best couple's costume and most original costume. Karaoke will be open all night and the kitchen will remain open until 1 a.m. Where: Singers Karaoke Club at 1345 Milton Ave., Solvay. When: Saturday, Oct. 31 at 9 p.m. How much: No cover charge. Bring your wallet for drinks and food. 
22. Halloween Masquerade The Center for the Arts of Homer will host a Halloween Masquerade with costume contests, door prizes and live music by Caravan of Thieves. The music of the Caravan of Thieves ranges from classic gypsy jazz with jump-blues-style vocals and dazzling guitar and violin instrumentals to a swing cover of a tune by the Talking Heads to a note-perfect rendition of Queen's "Bohemian Rhapsody." Anyone wearing a costume will receive one free drink or concession item. Where: Center for the Arts of Homer at 72 S. Main St., Homer. When: Saturday, Oct. 31 at 8 p.m. How much: $20 for general admission , $16 senior admission and $10 for students with ID. Kids younger than 18 are free to attend. Call (607) 749-4900. 
23. Black Magic Banquet Celebrate Halloween at Empire's downtown brewpub with spooky drink specials and DJ Clockz, spinning live from 11 p.m. to 2 a.m. Try a $3 Roasted Pumpkin Ale, featuring Critz Farm pumpkins, honey, maple syrup and an array of fall spices. Not in an ale mood? Order a $3 Poltergeist Punch (a traditional long island cocktail with a melon-lime twist) or $2 Jell-O shots. Where: Empire Brewing Company at 120 Walton St. When: Saturday, Oct. 31 at 11 p.m. How much: No cover charge. Bring your wallet for drinks and food. Alto Cinco at 526 Westcott St. File photo 
24. Alto Cinco Halloween party For the second year in a row, Alto Cinco will celebrate Halloween by turning the restaurant into a haunted house equipped for a monstrous party. Last year's inaugural Halloween party drew at least 200 people. This year, there will be live funk music by The Nasty Truth and the Hoffman Family Band, plus a midnight costume contest with prizes for wearers of the scariest, most creative and funniest costumes. DJMJ will host a dance party to finish out the night. Where: Alto Cinco at 526 Westcott St. When: Saturday, Oct. 31 at 11 p.m. How much: No cover charge. Bring your wallet for drinks and food. 
25. Turning Stone's 3 Nights of Horror All creatures of the night are invited to Turning Stone's 4th annual 3 Nights of Horror on October 29, 30 and 31. There will be Halloween costume contests each night with more than $10,000 in cash prizes to be awarded for categories like "Most Creative" and "Sexiest." All Exit 33 venues will be horrifically decorated for terrifying thrills and entertainment. Where: Exit 33 at Turning Stone Resort Casino at 5218 Patrick Rd., Verona. When: Oct. 29, 30 and 31. How much: Admission ranges from $15-60, depending on which venues you attend. See details at turningstone.com/nightlife-lounges/3-nights-of-horror .
